docs.title: TLDR
docs.text: AWS IAM is a global service. Its used in nearly all other services to control permissions and interaction boundaries in regards to resources and services in your account. Its also required to manage users in your AWS Account or AWSOrganisations. Permissions come in the form of groups, role and policies.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Dont use your root account for anything but account setup
  • One physical users should also be one AWS user
  • Assign users to groups and assign permissions to groups
  • Use a password policy to prevent weak passwords
  • Use and enforce MFA
  • Use roles for services
  • Use access keys for accessing services
  • Audit permissons with IAM Credential Report
  • Never share keys or user
  • Use least privilege principle

docs.title: Users
docs.text:
• Real persons
  • Can have multiple or no groups

docs.title: Groups
docs.text:
• Collection of users
  • One group can have multiple users

docs.title: Roles
docs.text:
• intended to be used by AWS Services
  • can be used to access cross account ressources

docs.title: Permission Boundary
docs.text:
• maximum permission employees can grant to other entities
  • uses managed policies
  • is attached to principal (which is the AWS Account)
  • can only be set on users and roles

docs.title: Policies
docs.text:
• Handles permissions
  • Attached to group, user or role as a json document.
  • Should use least privilege principle
  • If a user has multiple groups his permissions will be the composition of all policies of all groups
  • Deny always overwrites any alow 
    {
    "Version":"date", //required
    "Id":"string", //optional
    "Statement": [ // atleast 1 required
        {
            "Sid": "", // statement id optional
            "Effect" : "", // Allow | Deny
            "Principal" : "", // which account/user/role this should be applied to (only if used to attach to a ressource)
            "Action": [ // list of actions to deny or allow 
                "s3:putObject"
            ],
            "Ressource":["mybucket/*"], // list of ressource for which the actions are applied to
            "Condition": []//list of conditions for when this policy is applied, optional
        }
    ]
}

docs.title: TLDR
docs.text: AMIs are preconfigured EC2 Instance templates. Very similar to dockerfiles. But for EC2. AMIs alow further customisation of your instances, right on startup of an instance. You can create your own custom AMI or choose one aws and other users have already build.

docs.title: Custom AMI
docs.text:
• locked to region of creation, but can be manually copied to another region
  • faster boot time, because you wont have to install as many or no depenencies

docs.title: AWS Marketplace AMI
docs.text: • user created AMIs, these might cost money

docs.title: How to create your own AMI
docs.text:
• Start EC2instance
  • run scripts/setup and add all data you want the AMI to have
  • stop EC2 instance
  • build AMI (also creates an EBS Snapshot, if you delete this snapshot the AMI wont work)
  • Launch new instances with your freshly created AMI

docs.title: TLDR
docs.text: App Runner is a service similar to ElasticBeanstalk. It enabled developers to quickly deploy an application in AWS without having to manage any infrastructure or ressources.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Deploy web apps and api at scale
  • No infrastructure knowledge required
  • Start with source code or container image
  • Define cpu ram etc.
  • Deploy everything for you
  • Uses ECS with Fargate under the hood
  • Fully managed by AWS

docs.title: TLDR
docs.text: AWS Batch is used to simplify big batch jobs at scale. It handles to provisioning of computing, orchisation and storage power at a higher level.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Fully managed batch processing at any scale
  • Run 100ks of batch jobs
  • Batch job has an start or end
  • Dynamicly launch EC2 on-demand instances or spot instances
  • Can also use Fargate ECS
  • Helpful for cost optimisations
  • No infrastructure to manage
  • Not serverless
  • No time limit
  • Any runtime
  • Can use EBS or Instance store for diskspace

docs.title: Batch vs Lambda
docs.text:
• Lambda has a time Limit
  • Lambda has limited runtimes options
  • Lambda is serveress
  • Lambda has limited disk space

docs.title: TLDR
docs.text: EC2 is a the combination of a virtual mashine and hardware capacity attached to that vm in AWS. It is one of the oldest services and well integrated into most other services.

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
• OS (Win, Linux, MacOs)
  • CPU
  • RAM
  • Network attached storage (EBS & EFS)
  • Hardware attached (InstanceStore)
  • Network Card (Speed, Ip)
  • Firewall (SecurityGroup)
  • Bootstrap script (User Data)

docs.title: User Data
docs.text:
• Is a script is run once on the first start of the instance
  • Script is run using root privileges

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Installing updates
  • Installing software
  • Download files from the internet

docs.title: Type Definition
docs.text:
• Split by family
  • In family types are defined by Class.Generation.Size

docs.title: General Purpose
docs.text: • Balance between, computing, memory and network speed

docs.title: Compute Optimized
docs.text: • High cpu power

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Ml
  • Media Transcoding
  • HPC
  • Dedicated Gaming server

docs.title: Memory Optimized
docs.text: • High amount of RAM/Memory

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Process large data sets in memory
  • Non relational databases
  • Cache stores
  • In memory databases
  • Real time proccessing of big unstructured data

docs.title: Storage Optimzied
docs.text: • High amount of Disk IOPs

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Alot of Datasets in local storage
  • High frequency online transaction processing systems
  • Databases
  • Cache for in mem databases (e.g. redis)
  • Distributed file systems
  • Data warehouse applications

docs.title: On Demand
docs.text:
• Price by second
  • Use for short workload

docs.title: Default
docs.text:
• 1 Year OR 3 Years
  • Cheaper than on demand
  • Need to specify type os, region, tenacy
  • Cheaper if payed upfront
  • Scope reserve in zone and AZ
  • You can sell peer to peer in marketplace

docs.title: Convertiable
docs.text:
• More expensive than default
  • Can change instance type, os, region, tenacy

docs.title: SavingsPlans
docs.text:
• 1 Year OR 3 Years
  • Up to same discount as default reserved instance
  • Commit to an amount of usage (cpu, mem, disk)
  • Beyond commit is billed on demand price
  • Locked to instance family and region
  • Can change os, tenancy, and instance size

docs.title: Spot Instances
docs.text:
• Cheapest
  • Can lose instance
  • Define max price you are willing to pay, if you are overbid your instance is gone

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Short workloads
  • Suited for resiliant jobs
  • Distributed workloads (these are resiliant by definition)
  • batch jobs

docs.title: Dedicated Hosts
docs.text:
• Rent an entire physical server, control placement of that server
  • can use on demand or reserved
  • most expensive
  • can convert to dedicated instance

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Complicance
  • Server bound software licences

docs.title: Dedicated Instances
docs.text:
• No other customer will share the hardware used by you
  • Hardeware may be shared within same account
  • No control over instance placement (hardware might be moved)
  • can convert to dedicated host

docs.title: Capacity Reservations
docs.text:
• Reserve a capacity in a AZ for duration (on demand instance)
  • No time commitment
  • No billig discount
  • Combine with Saving plan and Reserved Instances for same AZ to save money
  • Charged on demand price if instance is not running

#### Use Cases - short term uninterrupted workload in a specific az

docs.title: Spot Instance
docs.text:
• Request for an instance and the instance running itself is diffrent
  • If you terminate your instance but not the request the instance will be relaunched
  • If you cancel your request your instance will still be running

docs.title: Spot Blocks
docs.text:
• Duration window of your Spot instance
  • 1 to 6 hours
  • designed to not be interrupted

docs.title: Fleet
docs.text:
• Define multiple options for instance type , region etc
  • Define a budget and target capacity
  • help to get spot instance with lowest price

docs.title: Strategies
docs.text:
• Lowest price, launch from lowest price pool
  • Diversified, launch from all pools (resiliance)
  • Capacity optimized, launch from pool with strongest capacity settings

docs.title: Elastic Ip
docs.text:
• A static ip which can be attached to Elastic Network Interfaces and other services
  • Used to mask a fail by keeping ip but changing machine ( when instance fail => redirect to another instance)
  • Up to 5 per account
  • Can request more than 5 from aws

docs.title: Placement Groups
docs.text: Placement strategy for a group ec2 instances

docs.title: Spread
docs.text:
• Multi AZ
  • Diffrent hardware
  • Limited to 7 instances per AZ per placement group
  • Use for critical apps and high availability

docs.title: Cluster
docs.text:
• Same rack
  • Fast internal connection from ec2 to ec2
  • Used for low latency and big data jobs with deadline
  • Rack fail -> all EC2s fail

docs.title: Partition
docs.text:
• Multi AZ
  • Multi rack but same rack per partition
  • Up to 7 partition per AZ

docs.title: Use Case
docs.text: • big data application which are partition aware

docs.title: ENI Elastic Network Interfaces
docs.text:
• Virtual Network Card
  • Can be used not only for ec2
  • Eth0 = primary ENI
  • Primary private ip
  • Can add multiple for multiple private ips
  • Can attach elastic ip
  • Can attach mac adress
  • Can attach and detach from instance
  • Bound by AZ

docs.title: EFA Elastic Fabric Adapter
docs.text:
• use to accelerate high performance computing by providing os bypass hardware interface
  • cannot be used for windows

docs.title: ENA Elastic Network Adapter
docs.text:
• use for high performance networking capabilities
  • slower than efa

docs.title: EC2 Hibernate
docs.text:
• Standby for EC2, ram is saved
  • Faster startup
  • Root EBS must be encrypted
  • ram must be less than 150 gb
  • Used for breaks in very long running tasks or if an instances takes very long to startup
  • Can last no longer than 60 days
  • Must be enabled before launch

docs.title: EC2 Instance Recover
docs.text:
• Creates a new EC2 instance which is identical to the previous ec2
  • recovers private and public ip, metadat, elastic ip, instandce id
  • data in memory is lost

docs.title: Limits
docs.text: • by default your account has a maximum limit for ec2 instances based on the total vcpu used, you can submit a request to increase that limit

docs.title: TLDR
docs.text: AWS Lambda means you dont care about any infrastructure, you just upload a function to aws. You can than use that function from other services like APIGateway, SNS or even CLI. You upload Lambda code as a zip.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Run code serverless
  • Pay per compute time
  • Scaling is automated
  • No charge if not running
  • Operates from AWS ownedVPC
  • By default only public traffic
  • You can enable function VPC access if you need private ressources from your VPC
  • Scale up based on request amount
  • Can set custom function timeout
  • Can be packaged and deployed as container images

docs.title: Drawbacks
docs.text:
• Limited by time SHORT EXECUTIONS
  • if you need both private and public ressources, you will have to enable VPC access and use a nat gateway to access the internet

docs.title: Lambda authorizer
docs.text:
• Send additonal info based of bearer token or request context
  • Is useful because you can skip having too lookup users inside of your function (you pass the user data)
  • Dont pass credentials! (Though you could)

docs.title: Compute Power
docs.text: • Relative to memory allocation which can be manually set

docs.title: Lambda Layer
docs.text:
• Zip archive which contains librarties, custom runtime and other dependecies
  • A single function can use up to 5 layers
  • Can use self created layers or already published ones
  • Unzipped size cannot exeed 250mb for a function and all layers which it depends on

docs.title: Container Image
docs.text:
• If using an image the image must implement the Lambda runtime api
  • ECS and Fargate are prefered for this use case

docs.title: Price
docs.text:
• Pay per call first 1 mill are free
  • 0.20 cent per one million request after
  • Pay per duration 400000GB-Seconds per month free
  • Price scales up after that depending on gbseconds (more will be cheaper per gbsecond)
